ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also had asynchronous days on Friday where we submitted a video presentation on a video and sets of questions
Virtual seminar with one day of an asynchronous component
There were live discussion sections twice a week and Fridays were recorded video homework.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed Arabic speaking and presenting skills and was introduced to a variety of Arabic stories. I picked up a lot of vocab used in news articles so found myself better able to engage with that.

By taking this course, I developed better presentation skills in Arabic. I also learned a lot of helpful vocabulary to talk about current events and diplomatic relations all while learning more about some of the current issues in the world today.
I learned to synthesize my ideas in Arabic better, both in speaking and writing, and learned to analyze difficult texts.
I gained knowledge in the Arabic language.
I had an opportunity to engage on a weekly basis in reading and speaking in modern standard arabic.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: I think class was very straightforward and structured
weakness: we didn't have much writing practice before the final essay and Mondays could have had more discussion instead of just going over answers

The strengths of the course are that we learn a lot of new and useful vocabulary and we use this vocabulary every week when we have to read the news and new articles. By the end of the course, I was able to read the news and understand most of it without having to constantly check a dictionary. The course could be improved in a few ways. I would have liked it if the class discussions were more interactive. Instead of talking about the answers to the questions that we did at home during breakout rooms, it would have been helpful to be assigned a question that we did not prepare in advance so we could practice thinking and speaking on the spot in Arabic. Rather than practicing presentations (which is also helpful, but I think it would be better if done every other week), I think it would be better to have more class discussion. I also think it would be useful to have more vocabulary quizzes in class or more writing assignments. Finally, I think this course could be improved by having more feedback on my assignments. Instead of just a grade, I would have liked explanations of what grammar and pronunciation mistakes I make so that I can improve this in the future. I think that it would have been helpful if we reviewed a grammar concept that maybe a lot of students are struggling with.

The materials and texts we engaged with were interesting. However, the structure wasn't set up in the best way to facilitate engagement. Instead of answering vocabulary questions after reading a passage, I think everyone would have benefited more and engaged more if we had a discussion to analyze and understand the text better. Additionally, the presentations we gave every Wednesday weren't very helpful, since people tended to zone out in other people's presentations.
The discussions were very helpful, however, it was hard to improve because I did not receive feedback quickly.

During the course I submitted about 30 oral assignments. I haven't received any feedback on any of them (bsdies a numerical grade, that does not have any meaning in a langauge course). Therefore, I haven't had any chance to improve my reading, writing or speaking during the entire term.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The flipgrid assignments were good in freeing up Fridays and allowed us to watch some interesting videos

The use of Flipgrid was helpful and I liked that we could see other students' responses and to see how they speak and pronounce words, but I think that perhaps it would be better to not have this component every week. Flipgrid is very interactive and fun, but I think that there should be more synchronous discussions. Kahoot was also a nice resource to practice the new vocabulary, but I think that there should be more quizzes to reinforce the vocabulary.
The online discussion sections worked pretty well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes I think I learned a lot so this class was a good L5 Arabic class that was not very stressful but still beneficial
I would recommend this course to another student because you will learn a lot of useful vocabulary and develop your presentation skills.

I wouldn't recommend this course to native speakers, because you will feel like you're not learning anything, but I think this class is good for students who want to become better readers and writers and speakers.
This course is the logical progression in the Arabic language, and it helped me improve my language skills, so I would recommend this course to anyone who wanted to achieve these goals.
The course would not allow students to seriously improve their Arabic speaking or writing skills.
